conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the tangent to the curve on a v-t graph.
If the slope is positive, the object is accelerating; if negative, it is decelerating. The magnitude of the slope indicates the magnitude of the acceleration.
At t = 0, the slope of the curve for object A is zero because the velocity starts from zero.
As time progresses, the slope of the curve for object A increases, indicating that the acceleration is increasing.
At some point before t1, the slope for object A reaches its maximum value.
After reaching the maximum, the slope for object A starts to decrease until it becomes zero again at t1.
The acceleration of object A first increases and then decreases.
At t = 0, the slope of the curve for object B is zero because the velocity starts from zero.
As time progresses, the slope of the curve for object B increases, indicating that the acceleration is increasing.
At some point before t1, the slope for object B reaches its maximum value.
After reaching the maximum, the slope for object B starts to decrease until it becomes zero again at t1.
The acceleration of object B first increases and then decreases.
The accelerations of both objects A and B are indeed first increasing and then decreasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
